newsitem.title: USA: Rep. Schumer to run for D'Amato's NY Senate seat.
newsitem.headline: Rep. Schumer to run for D'Amato's NY Senate seat.

text.p: Democratic Representative Charles Schumer of New York said Thursday he would run for the Senate next year against three-term Republican incumbent Alfonse D'Amato.
"I'm excited about my choice because I know it's the right fit," Schumer, 46, said in a statement.

"New Yorkers need a senator who will fight for more high- paying jobs, for better schools, for lower electric rates, for tougher gun control, for lower health care costs and for a woman's right to choose. I intend to be that senator," he added.
Schumer was first elected to the House in 1980 from Brooklyn. He is best known as one of the chief sponsors of the Brady bill, which imposed a five-day waiting period for handgun sales.

D'Amato, 59, was elected to the Senate in 1980 after defeating Republican incumbent Jacob Javits in a bitter primary and re-elected in 1986 and 1992. He is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee and is often called "Senator Pothole" because of the effort he makes to deal with local issues.
Asked about Schumer's candidacy, D'Amato told reporters in Washington, "Everybody has a right to run, even Chuck Schumer."

Several other New York Democrats including former D'Amato foe Mark Green and former Congresswoman and 1984 Democratic vice presidential nominee Geraldine Ferraro are thought to be considering a bid for their party's nomination to oppose D'Amato.
